| **[Reference](/wiki/Source_code "Source code")**                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        | [EvilHack - monst.c, line 594](https://github.com/k21971/EvilHack/blob/master/src/monst.c#L594) |

A **gnoll**, h, is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"). The gnoll is an [omnivorous](/wiki/Omnivorous "Omnivorous") [humanoid](/wiki/Humanoid_\(monster_class\) "Humanoid (monster class)") being and the most basic type of [gnoll](/wiki/Gnoll_\(monster_attribute\) "Gnoll (monster attribute)") that a character can encounter. A gnoll is [strong](/wiki/Strong "Strong"), has [infravision](/wiki/Infravision "Infravision"), can be seen via infravision, will seek out and pick up items such as weapons, armor and gold, and is capable of entering [a berserker rage](/wiki/Berserk_\(EvilHack\) "Berserk (EvilHack)").

A gnoll has a weapon attack and a bite attack, and possesses [poison resistance](/wiki/Poison_resistance "Poison resistance").

## Generation

Randomly generated gnolls are always created hostile, and may appear in large [groups](/wiki/Group "Group"). A gnoll can [grow up](/wiki/Grow_up "Grow up") into a [gnoll hunter](/wiki/Gnoll_hunter "Gnoll hunter").

A gnoll has a 3⁄4 chance of [being generated with](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") [armor](/wiki/Plain_armor "Plain armor") and an independent 1⁄5 chance of a [cloak](/wiki/Plain_cloak "Plain cloak"). They also have 3⁄4 chance of generating with either a [flail](/wiki/Flail "Flail") (2⁄3 chance) or a spear (1⁄3 chance) as their weapon, and will otherwise generate with a [voulge](/wiki/Voulge "Voulge") (1⁄3 chance) or a [morning star](/wiki/Morning_star "Morning star") (2⁄3 chance).

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Gnole](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gnole "wikipedia:Gnole")***

The gnoll is a creature that appears in various types of fantasy media, and is generally portrayed as a human-hyena hybrid or a form of humanoid hyena. The term originates from 1912 short story collection *[The Book of Wonder](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Book_of_Wonder "wikipedia:The Book of Wonder")* by [Lord Dunsany](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lord_Dunsany "wikipedia:Lord Dunsany"), with one short story titled "How Nuth Would Have Practised His Art upon the Gnoles".

The gnoll of *[Dungeons & Dragons](/wiki/Dungeons_%26_Dragons "Dungeons & Dragons")* is introduced in [the first boxed set](https://archive.org/details/monsters_and_treasures/page/7/mode/2up) of the game, and gnolls are described in *Book 2: Monsters and Treasure* as a "cross between [Gnomes](/wiki/Gnome "Gnome") and [Trolls](/wiki/Troll "Troll") (...perhaps, Lord Sunsany did not really make it all that clear)". These early gnolls were stated to be similar to hobgoblins with +2 morale, while a gnoll king and his bodyguard fought similar to trolls without regenerative power.

The 1st Monster Manual for *Advanced Dungeons & Dragons* and all subsequent material describe gnolls as aggressive desert-dwelling nomads that resemble humanoid hyenas, and actively raid and plunder other settlements; it also introduces [Yeenoghu](/wiki/Yeenoghu "Yeenoghu"), the demon god of gnolls who many of them serve and worship. This portrayal of gnolls is the basis for their appearance in EvilHack.

## Encyclopedia entry

We are born and we die.  
No one cares, no one remembers,  
and it doesn't matter.  
This is why we laugh.  
\[ The Gnoll Credo, by J. Stanton ]

Gnoll (EvilHack)

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
h gnoll
Difficulty 6
Attacks Weapon 1d6, Bite 1d4
h gnoll
Difficulty 6
Attacks

Weapon 1d6, Bite 1d4

Base level 4
Base experience 22
Speed 8
Base AC 7
Base MR 0
Alignment -10 (chaotic)
Frequency (by normal means) 2 (Quite rare)
Genocidable Yes
Weight 1200
Nutritional value 300
Size Medium
Resistances poison
Resistances conveyed None

A gnoll:

  • has a head, a couple of arms, and a torso.
  • is omnivorous.
  • is normally generated hostile.
  • is strong.
  • likes gold.
  • can pick up weapons and food.
  • has infravision.
  • can be seen through infravision.
  • normally appears in large groups.
Reference EvilHack - monst.c, line 594

A gnoll, h, is a type of monster that appears in EvilHack. The gnoll is an omnivorous humanoid being and the most basic type of gnoll that a character can encounter. A gnoll is strong, has infravision, can be seen via infravision, will seek out and pick up items such as weapons, armor and gold, and is capable of entering a berserker rage.

A gnoll has a weapon attack and a bite attack, and possesses poison resistance.

Generation

Randomly generated gnolls are always created hostile, and may appear in large groups. A gnoll can grow up into a gnoll hunter.

A gnoll has a 3⁄4 chance of being generated with armor and an independent 1⁄5 chance of a cloak. They also have 3⁄4 chance of generating with either a flail (2⁄3 chance) or a spear (1⁄3 chance) as their weapon, and will otherwise generate with a voulge (1⁄3 chance) or a morning star (2⁄3 chance).

Origin

Wikipedia has an article about:
Gnole

The gnoll is a creature that appears in various types of fantasy media, and is generally portrayed as a human-hyena hybrid or a form of humanoid hyena. The term originates from 1912 short story collection The Book of Wonder by Lord Dunsany, with one short story titled "How Nuth Would Have Practised His Art upon the Gnoles".

The gnoll of Dungeons & Dragons is introduced in the first boxed set of the game, and gnolls are described in Book 2: Monsters and Treasure as a "cross between Gnomes and Trolls (...perhaps, Lord Sunsany did not really make it all that clear)". These early gnolls were stated to be similar to hobgoblins with +2 morale, while a gnoll king and his bodyguard fought similar to trolls without regenerative power.

The 1st Monster Manual for Advanced Dungeons & Dragons and all subsequent material describe gnolls as aggressive desert-dwelling nomads that resemble humanoid hyenas, and actively raid and plunder other settlements; it also introduces Yeenoghu, the demon god of gnolls who many of them serve and worship. This portrayal of gnolls is the basis for their appearance in EvilHack.

Encyclopedia entry

We are born and we die.
No one cares, no one remembers,
and it doesn't matter.
This is why we laugh.
[ The Gnoll Credo, by J. Stanton ]

A '''gnoll''', {{brown|h}}, is a type of [[monster]] that appears in [[EvilHack]]. The gnoll is an [[omnivorous]] [[Humanoid (monster class)|humanoid]] being and the most basic type of [[Gnoll (monster attribute)|gnoll]] that a character can encounter. A gnoll is [[strong]], has [[infravision]], can be seen via infravision, will seek out and pick up items such as weapons, armor and gold, and is capable of entering [[Berserk (EvilHack)|a berserker rage]].

A gnoll has a weapon attack and a bite attack, and possesses [[poison resistance]].

==Generation==
Randomly generated gnolls are always created hostile, and may appear in large [[group]]s. A gnoll can [[grow up]] into a [[gnoll hunter]].

A gnoll has a {{frac|3|4}} chance of [[Monster starting inventory|being generated with]] [[Plain armor|armor]] and an independent {{frac|5}} chance of a [[Plain cloak|cloak]]. They also have {{frac|3|4}} chance of generating with either a [[flail]] ({{frac|2|3}} chance) or a spear ({{frac|3}} chance) as their weapon, and will otherwise generate with a [[voulge]] ({{frac|3}} chance) or a [[morning star]] ({{frac|2|3}} chance).

==Origin==
{{wikipedia|Gnole}}
The gnoll is a creature that appears in various types of fantasy media, and is generally portrayed as a human-hyena hybrid or a form of humanoid hyena. The term originates from 1912 short story collection ''[[wikipedia:The Book of Wonder|The Book of Wonder]]'' by [[wikipedia:Lord Dunsany|Lord Dunsany]], with one short story titled "How Nuth Would Have Practised His Art upon the Gnoles".

The gnoll of ''[[Dungeons & Dragons]]'' is introduced in [https://archive.org/details/monsters_and_treasures/page/7/mode/2up the first boxed set] of the game, and gnolls are described in ''Book 2: Monsters and Treasure'' as a "cross between [[Gnome]]s and [[Troll]]s (...perhaps, Lord Sunsany did not really make it all that clear)". These early gnolls were stated to be similar to hobgoblins with +2 morale, while a gnoll king and his bodyguard fought similar to trolls without regenerative power.

The 1st Monster Manual for ''Advanced Dungeons & Dragons'' and all subsequent material describe gnolls as aggressive desert-dwelling nomads that resemble humanoid hyenas, and actively raid and plunder other settlements; it also introduces [[Yeenoghu]], the demon god of gnolls who many of them serve and worship. This portrayal of gnolls is the basis for their appearance in EvilHack.
